issues.text: Whether the charge of a single general criminal conspiracy is not established because the facts proved establish multiple separate conspiracies (at least eight), each related to licences issued to one particular fictitious company?

anchor.surface_text: The charge of conspiracy framed against the appellant was a charge of a single conspiracy while the facts proved establish the existence of number only a single conspiracy but of at least eight conspiracies, each , single conspiracy being related to the issue of licences to one particular compan

issues.text: Whether Karmik, P.W. 20, was an accomplice and whether the High Court misread the evidence regarding intimate relationship between appellant and Karmik?

anchor.surface_text: y. The charge of conspiracy as laid is therefore number established. Karmik, P.W.20, was an accomplice on account of the circumstances urged, but the High Court misread the evidence by stating that there was a state of intimate relationship between the appellant and Karmik.

issues.text: Whether the handwriting expert should have been examined to prove the endorsement on the postal receipt was in the appellant's handwriting, especially since specimen writings were obtained, and whether adverse inference arises from not obtaining the opinion?

anchor.surface_text: The hand-writing expert should have been examined to prove that the endorsement on the postal receipt was in the handwriting of the appellant, especially when the in- vestigating officer had obtained specimen writings of the appellant. The High Court considered certain circumstances in justification of the failure of obtaining the opinion of the hand-writing expert

arguments.claim: Great reliance on R v Griffith to argue facts show multiple conspiracies, not single.

holdings.text: The conspiracy charged was a single general conspiracy to abuse official positions for issuing import licences to fictitious firms and share pecuniary benefits, not multiple separate conspiracies.

anchor.surface_text: The finding that the various firms to whom licences were issued were fictitious is number questioned. The companyspiracy was a general companyspiracy to keep on issuing licences in the names of fictitious firms and to share the benefits arising

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge describes general agreement among conspirators including unknown persons to misuse positions for bogus licences and shared profits; firms all fictitious with common modus operandi and knowledge; distinguishes R v Griffith where independent genuine parties lacked common scheme knowledge.

holdings.text: Karmik PW 20 is not an accomplice whose evidence requires corroboration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Karmik was public servant postman discharging duty by delivering registered mail on recipient's prior instruction without knowledge of conspiracy; prior official deliveries created familiarity, not intimacy implying complicity.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to examine a handwriting expert in every case of disputed handwriting.

holdings.text: No adverse inference under s.114 illustration (g) Evidence Act arises from prosecution's failure to obtain handwriting expert opinion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption applies only to withholding obtained evidence, not mere omission to obtain; impossible to presume unfavourable outcome without evidence existing.

holdings.text: The High Court erroneously used appellant's delay in meeting Joint Chief Controller as corroboration of Karmik's evidence since no evidence supported guilty mind inference and circumstance not put to accused under s.342 CrPC; however, unnecessary as Karmik not accomplice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstance lacked evidential basis, not put to accused denying opportunity to explain; cannot infer guilt from delay alone; but belief in non-accomplice witness needs no corroboration.

holdings.text: The conviction of the appellant under s.120B r/w s.409 IPC and s.5(2) r/w s.5(1)(d) Prevention of Corruption Act is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects all contentions; upholds lower courts' findings on single conspiracy, Karmik's credible non-accomplice testimony proving receipt of fictitious firm licences, and appellant's membership thereof; no evidentiary gaps warrant acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: Great reliance is placed on the case reported as R. v. Griffith  1  in support of the companytention that the facts established make out the case of eight companyspiracies instead of the single companyspiracy charged. That case is very much different. In that case, a supplier of lime and his book- keeper and various individual farmers were charged with companyspiring to companymit fraud and obtain money by false pre- tences from the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries and Food on account of lime subsidy. It was established that there was number link as between one farmer and another.

precedents.cited_proposition: To constitute one conspiracy among multiple parties, there must be evidence that each knew of and attached themselves to a larger scheme involving others beyond their individual act, so all act in pursuance of a common criminal purpose; otherwise, separate conspiracies exist.
precedents.cited_holding: held that to constitute one conspiracy between all the farmers and the supplier of lime there had to be evidence from which it could be inferred that each farmer knew that there was or was coming into existence a scheme to which he attached himself to which there were other parties and which went beyond the act that he agreed to do so that all would be shown to have been acting in pursuance of the common criminal purpose

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the companyviction of the appellant is companyrect.
